AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: The only apparent AI quality issue (a garbled/empty user input) appears in an internal ATLAS transcript, not in customer-facing/public content. The customer did not report the AI being wrong or unhelpful in any public reply.
evidence: ATLAS commented privately: "Here is a transcript of the customer's recent interaction with ATLAS chat:"

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: There is no customer-facing evidence that the customer asked for a human and remained stuck with AI responses. The AI interaction shown is in a private transcript and the subsequent substantive replies are from human agents.
evidence: ATLAS chat transcript (private): "Ian DeMoss:\n\n raise a ticket"
Marcio (public): "Hi Ian,\n\nThank you for contacting the Exinda Support Team."

IGNORING_CONTEXT.reasoning: Support engaged with the customer’s question about whether a release fixes the 'no policy' issue and checked release notes; there’s no clear instance of requesting the same information after the customer said it was already provided, nor an explicit customer complaint about repetition.
evidence: Customer (public): "Can you confirm that the 7.6.0 version fixes the ‘no policy’ bug that is shown when clustering is enabled..."
Support (public): "There is no mention of a specific \"no policy\" bugfix."

RESPONSE_DELAYS.reasoning: The visible customer-to-staff reply gaps are under the thresholds (no 5+ day gap; no two separate 3+ day gaps). The customer asked for movement once, but the next staff response came within ~3 days.
evidence: Customer (private): "Has there been any movement on generating an updated Exinda code version..."
Support (public, ~2.7 days later): "Exinda version 7.6.0 is now available..."

PREMATURE_CLOSURE.reasoning: Support included an auto-closure warning, but there is no text indicating the ticket actually closed/was closed while the customer still awaited a pending answer. The warning is conditional and repeated, without a subsequent closure notice in the provided interactions.
evidence: Support (public): "This ticket will stay open for one week unless you reply with \"This ticket can be closed\" or update the status to Completed..."
Support (public): "This ticket will stay open for one week unless you reply with \"This ticket can be closed\"..."

P1_SEV1_MISHANDLING.reasoning: The customer did not describe an outage, production-down condition, or explicitly label severity (P1/SEV1/critical). Support’s responses focused on release notes/upgrade guidance rather than treating an explicitly critical incident as routine.
evidence: Customer (public): "...the ‘no policy’ bug that is shown when clustering is enabled..."
Support (public): "The only clustering-related bugfix I see in the release notes... There is no mention of a specific \"no policy\" bugfix."
